questions.text: A 31-year-old man, who was hospitalized for substance-induced psychosis two days ago, has had episodic neck stiffness and pain for the past 8 hours. These episodes last for approximately 25 minutes and are accompanied by his neck rotating to the right. During the last episode, he was able to relieve the stiffness by lightly touching his jaw. He has received six doses of haloperidol for auditory hallucinations since his admission. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 108/min, and blood pressure is 128/86 mm Hg. Examination shows a flexed neck rotated to the right. The neck is rigid with limited range of motion. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia manifests with painful torticollis (as seen here), opisthotonus, oculogyric crisis, trismus, tongue spasm, and/or laryngospasm. Risk factors include male sex and young age. This condition's pathophysiology is incompletely understood but an imbalance between dopaminergic activity in the indirect pathway of the basal ganglia (due to D2 receptor antagonism by the antipsychotic) and cholinergic transmission in the striatum is thought to play a role. A centrally acting anticholinergic drug such as benztropine or diphenhydramine is the first-line treatment for neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia (see “Overview of extrapyramidal symptoms” table).

The role of cholinergic transmission in the pathophysiology of neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia is also supported by the observation that the risk of acute dystonia is lower with low-potency typical antipsychotics, which have an anticholinergic effect and a weaker antidopaminergic effect when compared with high-potency typical antipsychotics.

B) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy can be used as an adjunctive treatment for this patient's condition. However, highly effective, well-tolerated pharmacotherapy would be the first-line intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Dantrolene is a skeletal muscle relaxant used to treat malignant hyperthermia, neuroleptic malignant syndrome, and (severe) chronic spasticity resulting from upper motor neuron damage (e.g., stroke, multiple sclerosis). Although the patient suffers from spasticity in his neck, the condition is acute and not chronic. In addition, since dantrolene may also cause psychiatric side effects (e.g., depression, confusion, insomnia), it should be given with caution in patients with a history of psychiatric symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Baclofen is a GABA receptor agonist commonly used as a muscle relaxant to treat spasticity. However, it shows little effect in the treatment of secondary dystonia (e.g., medication-induced acute dystonia) and would only be indicated after other preferred treatments have failed. Baclofen is usually used for treating primary dystonia (idiopathic, hereditary) and is more effective in children and adolescents than in adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is the first-line treatment for akathisia, which is the most common extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotic drugs. While this patient is at risk for akathisia, it is characterized by restlessness, fidgeting, and/or pacing. Instead, this patient's cervical muscle spasms are characteristic of another extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics.
questions.hint: The repeated episodes of painful neck stiffness are suggestive of acute dystonia, an extrapyramidal side effect that typically occurs within a few days of initiating or increasing the dose of a high-potency typical antipsychotic (e.g., haloperidol).

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 43-year-old woman comes to the physician because of several episodes of involuntary movement of her head over the past few months. These episodes are sometimes associated with neck pain and can last minutes to hours. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. During examination of the neck, the patient's head turns to the left. She states this movement is involuntary, and that she is unable to keep her head from turning. After 5 minutes, she is able to straighten her head again. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's clinical findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Akathisia is a movement disorder characterized by an intense urge to move. Affected individuals have difficulty sitting still and typically exhibit fidgety behavior (e.g., pacing, rocking). Movements are characteristically voluntary, repetitive, and driven by a subjective sense of restlessness, unlike this patient's involuntary, nonrepetitive head movement. Akathisia is most commonly seen as a side-effect of antipsychotic medications and antiparkinson medications, which this patient is not taking.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemiballismus is an involuntary movement disorder characterized by large amplitude movements of one side of the body (e.g., flinging of an arm or leg), and may indicate a lesion of the contralateral subthalamic nucleus. Sustained contraction of a single muscle, as observed here, is not a feature of hemiballismus.

C) INCORRECT:

Myoclonus is an involuntary movement disorder characterized by multiple, brief, shock-like twitches caused by sudden muscular contraction or inhibition. Sustained contraction of a muscle, as seen in this patient, is not a feature of myoclonus.

D) CORRECT:

Dystonia is a movement disorder characterized by episodic, prolonged, involuntary muscular contractions. The patient presents with involuntary contractions of the right sternocleidomastoid muscle (head turns to the left) in the absence of other neurological signs. This is typical of spasmodic torticollis, the most common form of focal dystonia. Spasmodic torticollis is often idiopathic and typically manifests for the first time after the age of 30. Focal dystonia responds well to botulinum toxin injections.

E) INCORRECT:

Chorea is an involuntary movement disorder characterized by continuous, jerky, purposeless movements that cannot be suppressed. It is a sign of a lesion in the basal ganglia and is typically seen in Huntington disease or acute rheumatic fever (Sydenham chorea). Chorea typically affects the limbs and/or face. Sustained contraction of a muscle, as seen in this patient, is not a feature of chorea.

F) INCORRECT:

Athetosis is an involuntary movement disorder characterized by continuous, nonrhythmic, low-amplitude, slow, writhing movements. It can develop secondary to basal ganglia and/or thalamic damage (e.g., Huntington disease in adults; cerebral palsy and kernicterus in children). Sustained contraction of a muscle, as seen in this patient, is not a feature of athetosis. Furthermore, athetosis typically affects the hands and feet, and only rarely the face and neck.
questions.hint: Other common examples of this disorder include blepharospasm and writer's cramp.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man presents for evaluation of a runny nose and tingling of his forehead that started 6 months ago. He attributes his symptoms to a tracking device the government implanted in his brain as part of a project to develop remote mind control. He claims the device runs commentaries on his daily activities, inserts new thoughts while deleting his own, and broadcasts his ideas to government agencies.
During the interview, the patient becomes acutely agitated and threatening toward staff. A decision is made to treat the agitation with intramuscular haloperidol.
Which one of the following medications is indicated to reduce the risk of acute dystonia in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute drug-induced dystonia is characterized by a sustained abnormal posture or muscle spasm that develops after receipt of a dopamine-blocking agent, such as an antipsychotic, antiemetic, or antidepressant. Risk factors for acute drug-induced dystonia include young age, male sex, neuroleptic-naive status, cocaine use, and a history of acute dystonia. High-potency antipsychotic drugs, such as haloperidol, cause dystonia more frequently than low-potency drugs.

A prophylactic anticholinergic drug, such as benztropine, is recommended when first-generation antipsychotic drugs are initiated in patients who are at high risk for developing drug-induced dystonia, particularly neuroleptic-naive patients who are acutely psychotic.

Dystonia is a potentially frightening side effect that may scare a patient away from continuing with the needed treatment, so benztropine to help reduce the risk of dystonia is particularly prudent when initiating a first-generation antipsychotic to an acutely agitated psychotic patient.

Key learning point: Dystonia resulting from a first-generation antipsychotic drug, such as haloperidol, can be prevented by coadministering an anticholinergic drug, such as benztropine.

B) INCORRECT:

Anticonvulsants (e.g., carbamazepine) are not indicated to prevent or treat the extrapyramidal side effects of first-generation antipsychotics.

C) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol) are used to mitigate the extrapyramidal side effects of dopamine-blocking agents, but they are not indicated for preventing acute dystonic reaction.

D) INCORRECT:

Muscle relaxants (e.g., cyclobenzaprine) are not indicated to prevent or treat the extrapyramidal side effects of first-generation antipsychotics.

E) INCORRECT:

Benzodiazepines (e.g., alprazolam) are used to mitigate the extrapyramidal side effects of dopamine-blocking agents, but they are not indicated for preventing acute dystonic reaction.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman reports a 2-year history of tremors that began in her left hand, gradually progressed to involve her right hand, and now cause her to spill food when she is eating. She also mentions that her handwriting has become smaller during the past 2 years. Her spouse notes that she seems to have “slowed down” overall.
She has a 20-year history of bipolar disorder and has been taking aripiprazole 30 mg daily for the past 4 years. She also takes atorvastatin, levothyroxine, and insulin. She took lithium for several years but discontinued it 5 years ago because of changes in her thyroid hormone levels. Review of systems reveals no sleep disturbances, hyposmia, or bowel or bladder problems. She denies any history of alcohol or tobacco use.
Her physical examination is significant for reduced emotional expression, slow but pressured speech, general paucity of gestures, and reduced global spontaneity of movements. She has a low-amplitude, high-frequency rest tremor of both hands, worse on the right side. Her tremor also has a slight postural component and a kinetic component on finger-to-nose testing. She has mild-to-moderate bradykinesia with reduced amplitude of finger- and foot-tapping. She has moderate rigidity, worse on the right side of the body. She has no dysmetria on finger-to-nose and heel-to-shin testing. Her strength, sensation of light and sharp touch, and deep-tendon reflexes are all normal. She walks with a stooped posture and drags her right foot. Tandem gait and balance testing are both normal.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Switch the patient from aripiprazole to lamotrigine
Obtain MRI of the brain with and without gadolinium

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Antipsychotic medications, such as aripiprazole, are well-described causes of drug-induced parkinsonism whose clinical features are largely indistinguishable from those of idiopathic parkinsonism. Various combinations of resting and mixed tremors, micrographia, bradykinesia, rigidity, shuffling of gait, and postural instability have been described in the literature. This form of parkinsonism can be reversed by discontinuing the offending medication: it can take up to 6 months off the medication to see full recovery. In this case, the patient’s aripiprazole should be switched to a medication that is likely to help stabilize her mood without causing adverse motor effects — for example, lamotrigine. Other drugs frequently associated with parkinsonism include certain antiemetic drugs and, less commonly, valproic acid.

Key learning point: The best treatment for drug-induced parkinsonism is discontinuation of the offending medication.

B) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the brain is not usually helpful in the absence of focal findings on neurologic examination, such as unilateral weakness, visual field loss, or aphasia.

C) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced parkinsonism may respond to dopamine agonists such as ropinirole or to levodopa itself; however, prescribing these medications without ruling out secondary causes of parkinsonism is not recommended and could complicate diagnosis in the future.

D) INCORRECT:

A dopamine transporter scan could help distinguish neurodegenerative parkinsonism from drug-induced parkinsonism. However, the test is expensive and may yield indeterminate results in the early stages of parkinsonism. It could be considered if the patient’s symptoms are not reversed by discontinuing the suspected causative medication.

E) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced parkinsonism may respond to dopamine agonists such as ropinirole or to levodopa itself; however, prescribing these medications without ruling out secondary causes of parkinsonism is not recommended and could complicate diagnosis in the future.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with two days of severe nausea and vomiting. She receives intravenous metoclopramide to relieve her symptoms. One hour later, she experiences abrupt muscle contractions in her neck and orofacial muscles, with her eyes deviated upward. She denies trauma or other neurologic complaints. Vital signs are normal, and she remains alert and oriented.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Urgent CT scan of the head

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While lorazepam has muscle relaxant properties, it does not address the cholinergic overactivity caused by dopamine receptor blockade in acute dystonic reactions. Anticholinergic agents, such as diphenhydramine, are preferred for directly counteracting the excessive cholinergic stimulation responsible for dystonic symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

A CT scan is unnecessary given the clear temporal relationship between metoclopramide administration and the onset of symptoms. The patient's normal vital signs and alertness further reduce the likelihood of an intracranial process. The symptoms are consistent with a drug-induced dystonic reaction, not a structural brain issue.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous dopamine infusion is not appropriate for treating drug-induced acute dystonic reactions. These reactions result from an imbalance between dopaminergic and cholinergic activity, not a deficiency of dopamine itself. Dopamine infusion is primarily used for cardiovascular support in hypotension or shock, not for modulating central neurotransmitter disturbances.

D) CORRECT:

The patient exhibits an acute dystonic reaction following metoclopramide administration, characterized by involuntary muscle contractions and ocular deviation. Metoclopramide, a dopamine receptor antagonist, can cause an imbalance between dopaminergic and cholinergic activity in the basal ganglia. Intravenous diphenhydramine, with its anticholinergic properties, effectively restores this balance and alleviates symptoms, making it the preferred treatment for drug-induced dystonia.

Key learning point: Acute dystonic reactions caused by dopamine receptor antagonists like metoclopramide can be effectively treated with diphenhydramine, an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties.

questions.text: You are caring for a 31-year-old man who was hospitalized two days ago for substance-induced psychosis. He has developed episodic neck stiffness and pain over the past 8 hours. Each episode lasts about 25 minutes and is associated with his neck rotating to the right. He reports that during the last episode, he was able to relieve the stiffness by lightly touching his jaw. He has received six doses of haloperidol for auditory hallucinations since admission. His temperature is 37.3°C, pulse is 108/min, and blood pressure is 128/86 mm Hg. On examination, his neck is flexed and rotated to the right, with rigidity and limited range of motion. Which one of the following is the most appropriate therapy for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Baclofen is a GABA receptor agonist commonly used as a muscle relaxant to treat spasticity. However, it shows little effect in the treatment of secondary dystonia (e.g., medication-induced acute dystonia) and would only be indicated after other preferred treatments have failed. Baclofen is usually used for treating primary dystonia (idiopathic, hereditary) and is more effective in children and adolescents than in adults.

B) CORRECT:

Neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia manifests with painful torticollis (as seen here), opisthotonus, oculogyric crisis, trismus, tongue spasm, and/or laryngospasm. Risk factors include male sex and young age. This condition's pathophysiology is incompletely understood but an imbalance between dopaminergic activity in the indirect pathway of the basal ganglia (due to D2 receptor antagonism by the antipsychotic) and cholinergic transmission in the striatum is thought to play a role. A centrally acting anticholinergic drug such as benztropine or diphenhydramine is the first-line treatment for neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia (see “Overview of extrapyramidal symptoms” table).

The role of cholinergic transmission in the pathophysiology of neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia is also supported by the observation that the risk of acute dystonia is lower with low-potency typical antipsychotics, which have an anticholinergic effect and a weaker antidopaminergic effect when compared with high-potency typical antipsychotics.

Key learning point: Neuroleptic-induced acute dystonia is best treated with centrally acting anticholinergic agents such as benztropine or diphenhydramine.

C) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy can be used as an adjunctive treatment for this patient's condition. However, highly effective, well-tolerated pharmacotherapy would be the first-line intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is the first-line treatment for akathisia, which is the most common extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotic drugs. While this patient is at risk for akathisia, it is characterized by restlessness, fidgeting, and/or pacing. Instead, this patient's cervical muscle spasms are characteristic of another extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics.

E) INCORRECT:

Dantrolene is a skeletal muscle relaxant used to treat malignant hyperthermia, neuroleptic malignant syndrome, and (severe) chronic spasticity resulting from upper motor neuron damage (e.g., stroke, multiple sclerosis). Although the patient suffers from spasticity in his neck, the condition is acute and not chronic. In addition, since dantrolene may also cause psychiatric side effects (e.g., depression, confusion, insomnia), it should be given with caution in patients with a history of psychiatric symptoms.
questions.hint: The repeated episodes of painful neck stiffness are suggestive of acute dystonia, an extrapyramidal side effect that typically occurs within a few days of initiating or increasing the dose of a high-potency typical antipsychotic (e.g., haloperidol).

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to your clinic because of several episodes of involuntary head movement over the past few months. These episodes are sometimes associated with neck pain and can last from minutes to hours. Neurologic examination is normal. During examination of her neck, her head turns to the left. She reports that this movement is involuntary and that she is unable to prevent her head from turning. After 5 minutes, she is able to straighten her head again. Which one of the following is the most likely explanation for her clinical findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Myoclonus is an involuntary movement disorder characterized by multiple, brief, shock-like twitches caused by sudden muscular contraction or inhibition. Sustained contraction of a muscle, as seen in this patient, is not a feature of myoclonus.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemiballismus is an involuntary movement disorder characterized by large amplitude movements of one side of the body (e.g., flinging of an arm or leg), and may indicate a lesion of the contralateral subthalamic nucleus. Sustained contraction of a single muscle, as observed here, is not a feature of hemiballismus.

C) CORRECT:

Dystonia is a movement disorder characterized by episodic, prolonged, involuntary muscular contractions. The patient presents with involuntary contractions of the right sternocleidomastoid muscle (head turns to the left) in the absence of other neurological signs. This is typical of spasmodic torticollis, the most common form of focal dystonia. Spasmodic torticollis is often idiopathic and typically manifests for the first time after the age of 30. Focal dystonia responds well to botulinum toxin injections.

Key learning point: Dystonia is characterized by episodic, prolonged, involuntary muscle contractions that can cause abnormal postures or repetitive movements, such as spasmodic torticollis.

D) INCORRECT:

Chorea is an involuntary movement disorder characterized by continuous, jerky, purposeless movements that cannot be suppressed. It is a sign of a lesion in the basal ganglia and is typically seen in Huntington disease or acute rheumatic fever (Sydenham chorea). Chorea typically affects the limbs and/or face. Sustained contraction of a muscle, as seen in this patient, is not a feature of chorea.

E) INCORRECT:

Akathisia is a movement disorder characterized by an intense urge to move. Affected individuals have difficulty sitting still and typically exhibit fidgety behavior (e.g., pacing, rocking). Movements are characteristically voluntary, repetitive, and driven by a subjective sense of restlessness, unlike this patient's involuntary, nonrepetitive head movement. Akathisia is most commonly seen as a side-effect of antipsychotic medications and antiparkinson medications, which this patient is not taking.
questions.hint: Other common examples of this disorder include blepharospasm and writer's cramp.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 6-hour history of involuntary fixed head posture. He was started on haloperidol 48 hours ago for acute psychosis. Physical examination shows sustained contraction of the right sternocleidomastoid muscle, with the head tilted to the right and rotated to the left. Gently touching his chin temporarily reduces the severity of torticollis. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has acute drug-induced dystonia from haloperidol, a high-potency typical antipsychotic. Benztropine is an anticholinergic agent that is a first-line treatment for acute dystonic reactions caused by dopamine antagonists. The drug should be administered immediately to reverse the dystonic symptoms. Other first-line treatment options include antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine).

B) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is a beta blocker that is a first-line treatment for akathisia, another type of extrapyramidal symptom caused by antipsychotics. Propranolol is not indicated for acute drug-induced dystonic reactions.

C) INCORRECT:

Amantadine is a dopamine agonist that may be used for pseudoparkinsonism, another extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics. Amantadine is not indicated for acute drug-induced dystonic reactions.

D) INCORRECT:

Botulinum toxin injection is typically used periodically to treat chronic focal dystonia, it is not appropriate for acute drug-induced dystonia.

E) INCORRECT:

Levodopa is primarily used for childhood-onset dystonia and other levodopa-responsive extrapyramidal disorders, it is not appropriate for acute drug-induced dystonia.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 6-hour history of involuntary neck muscle contractions causing his head to twist to the left. He reports jaw stiffness and difficulty speaking. His girlfriend mentions he was started on a new medication 3 days ago for auditory hallucinations. On examination, he appears anxious and has a sustained cervical muscle spasm with his head fixed in a rotated position. Vital signs are normal. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is the first-line treatment for akathisia, which manifests with restlessness and an urge to move rather than sustained muscle contractions. This patient's torticollis due to involuntary muscle spasm is characteristic of dystonia, not akathisia.

B) INCORRECT:

Amantadine is a dopamine agonist used primarily for pseudoparkinsonism, not acute dystonia.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Diphenhydramine is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties that effectively treats acute dystonic reactions. This patient's presentation is consistent with acute dystonia following the initiation of an antipsychotic, characterized by sustained muscle contractions of the head and neck occurring within hours to days of drug exposure. Certain antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine) and anticholinergics (e.g., benztropine) are first-line treatments that rapidly reverse the dopamine-acetylcholine imbalance in the basal ganglia.

D) INCORRECT:

While discontinuing the causative antipsychotic may eventually resolve the dystonia, it is not the appropriate initial management for an acute dystonic reaction. This patient requires immediate symptomatic treatment to relieve the painful muscle spasm, and abrupt discontinuation of antipsychotic medication may worsen the underlying psychiatric condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Cyclobenzaprine is a muscle relaxant used for muscle spasticity rather than acute dystonia. While it may provide some symptomatic relief for muscle contractions, it does not address the underlying dopamine-acetylcholine imbalance in the basal ganglia that causes acute dystonic reactions. Anticholinergics or antihistamines are preferred because they specifically counteract the extrapyramidal effects of antipsychotic medications.
